document.text: zon. And, in looking straight up at the Northern Cross, Vega will be seen about one-fourth of the way toward the horizon dug west. Further, the Little Dipper will be seen almost midway between the Northern Cross and the Big Dipper, that is, in the middle north western sky. An interesting star in the Sep tember sky is Altair. Altair will be found about one-third of the dis tance to the southern horizon from the Northern Cross. It is a bright star and one of our closest neigh bors. It is not a large star, but it is bright because it is so close only fifeen light years away.

document.text: Zedekiah was made king of Judah by the king of Babylon 2417, but in spite of this kindness and the word of the Lord spoken to him by Jeremiah Jer. 3817, 18 cf. Jer. 523, he re belled against the king of Babylon. He relied upon the help of Egypt, but all that Egypt could do was to cause temporary interruption of the siege of Jerusalem. I. The Seige of Jerusalem vv. 1-3. 1. Time of vv. 1, 2. It began on the tenth day of the tenth month of the ninth year of Zedekiahs reign and -lasted about eighteen months. The tenth month according to the Jewish calendar corresponds to our December- January, as their calendar year began about the middle of March. The reason the exact time is given is that this was to be an event of great importance to the Jews in their exile. 2. The Method v. 1. Nebuchadnez zar came in person with a large army and encamped against Jerusalem and built forts against it round about. It is thought that siege walls were built, around the city, shotting it in. On the tops Of these walls forts were built from which missiles of destruction could be hurled by their engines of war against the city. With the city shut in its fall was only a question of time. 3. The Famine v. 3. Gelkie says It was speedily followed, as is always the case, with an outbreak of pesti lence. Food was well-nigh gone. There had long been no bread. Moth ers were at last driven to murder and eat their children. Tlie richest citi zens wandering about searching for scraps in the dunghills. Even outside the city the people were starving. There was no bread for the people of the land. It is estimated that one- third of the people of Jerusalem died of starvation. II. Zedekiahs Flight and Fate vv. 4-7. 1. The City was Broken Up v. 4. The Chaldeans had succeeded in mak ing an opening in the wall so large that they could make their way into the. city in spite of all that the He brews could do. Resistance was car ried on to the bitter end. 2. Zedekiahs Flight v. 4. The king with his men of war fled by night to ward the plain. His object, no doubt, was to cross the Jordan at Jericho and hide in the mountains east of Jordan. 3. Zedekiahs Fate vv. 5-7. 1 He was overtaken in the plains of Jericho v. 5. When his flight was. discovered the Chaldean army pursued and cap tured him. 2 He was brought to the king of Babylon at Riblah v. 6. Riblah was a town north of Damascus. It was the kings headquarters from which he directed his armies against Tyre and Jerusalem. Before Neb uchadnezzar, Zedekiah was tried as a criminal. 3 His.fate v. 7. His sons were slain in his sight his eyes were put out he was bound with fet ters of brass and they carried him to Babylon where he remained pris oner until the day of his death Jer. 5211. III. Jerusalem Destroyed vv. 8-10. The dismantling of the city was de layed a month, perhaps awaiting in structions from Nebuchadnezzar, who was at Riblah. 1. They Burnt the House of the Lord v. 9. This was the sacred temple built by Solomon with additions and modifications. Before burning it they plundered it of all its sacred contents. 2. Burnt the Kings House v. 9. This was doubtless the palace built by Solomon. 3. Burnt All the Houses of Jeru salem v. 9. The implication is that the common houses were left for he people v. 12. 4. They Broke Down the Walls of Jerusalem. The aim was to render the walls useless as a means of de fense. IV. The Disposition of tho People vv. 11, 12. 1. Carried Them Into Captivity v. 11. The people who were left In the city and those who had deserted to the Babylonians were carried to Baby lon all such as would be of use in Babylon. 2. The Poorest of the Land Were Left v. 12. The people who would not likely make any trouble were left as vine-dressers and husbandmen Doubtless they were looking forward to colonization by foreign peoples. The object in leaving these people was that the country might be ready for their coming. Over these people Gedaliah was appointed as governor, with head quarters at Mizpah.

Those making a  I trip to South America had bet- - ter not bother with cargo ships  or airplanes but take one of the - regular passenger steamships  from New York anT return. This takes  around 50 days and costs nearly Z  1,000 per person  two in a  stateroom. The Moore-McCor-  mack Lines sail south from New ,  York down the East Coast, in- l I eluding Brazil and Argentina.  This trip does not take so long a time and therefore costs less. - Persons desiring to do so can go  south by the Grace Line, cross - the Ande and go on to the  East Coast by rail, and come - back by the Moore-McCormaCk Line. document.text: You have invited several friends to your home for a dinner party. You and your guests are seated at the dining room table, enjoying conver sation and a rib roast dinner. Sud denly, one of the guests begins coughing and making choking signs. A piece of meat has lodged in his throat, and he is unable to breathe. Precious seconds separate your friend from death. What would you. do if this life- threatening emergency occurred in your home? Would your knowledge of first aid enable you to save your friends lifeor would you stand by helplessly, watching him choke to death on a piece of rib roast? Medical experts agree that the first few minutes following an accident or attack are often the most critical and that prompt action may veiy well mean the difference between life and death. Unfortunately, thousands of Americahs die each year because the people who are in a position to help them during those first critical min utes dont know what action to take. The American Red Cross has long been a leader in developing and pro moting safety courses designed to

document.text: YOU E N JO Y T H E PRO TEC  TIO N , PA Y FO U IT The multi-millionaires enjoj more protection than do the rest of us and should pay for it without protest. The men who simply write checks to pay taxes have an easy time of it, compared with toe poor man who has to deny himself or family some comfort to pay a few dollars of taxes. A n d then, when the battle is joined this same poor man will be found on the forefront of bat tie, while the rich continue to enjoy the luxuries of their pa latial homes, losing no sleep of nights and no creature com forts from the table. And if the American multis are not willing to pay the war tax on this side the water, let them cross over to England and learn that they have exchanged the frying pan for the fire. The soldier who dodges duty is stamped with the mark of de serter and what of the rich who dodge the tax-gatherer? Can he not be shamed into do ing his duty? The soldier is shot for not doing his. Let rich and poor do duty, and alls well.

document.text: You are inviteli Richard B.1 JESUS IS YOUR FRIEND Perhaps you have suffered some great sorrow or disap pointment. Perhaps, you have been betrayed by friends in whom you placed your trust. Tt could be that you have been hurt by some injustice, some kind of hatred against which you have found it impossible to struggle. . It is at times like these that I there comes to you a hunger to know a better and a strongr friend, a truer and a wiser justice, a filler and a fairer life than you have ever lived before. Well, my dear friend, there is Someone you can turn to He loves you! He cares for you! He even died for you! Yes, He died for you, so that you could have eternal life. This dear friend is Jesus! He died on Calvarys cross so that you might have eternal life. Shouldnt you love Him for at least that much? Do you know Jesus? Is He a part of your life? Do you trust Him? You can trust Him. He is your friend. Yes, sinner, He is even your friend. Can you admit to yourself that you are a sinner? If you can, then you have taken a giant step in the direction of being closer to Jesus. If you are saved, then you know that you are on your way to heaven, but if youre not, dear friend, youre headed straight for hell. Dont you think that its time for you to get right with Jesus? Go to church, read your Bible daily, and pray continually. But, first of all, admit that you are a sinner and ask Jesus to come into your heart and save you from all sin. he is your i friend, and He will do it!

document.text: y REN J. BENNETT Nc unfinished nwers ór un won wars with God In Lukes Gospel, chapter 1428-82, Jesus illustrated the common problem of iinfinithedi business with two brief parables the parable of - an impulsive farmer who began to build an elaborate farm-building but did not finirii due to a lack of funds the parable of  a rash king who declared, war on a nation but did not win due to a tack of soldiers and military power. Unfinished business is the obvious problem in these parables, but what of the application to your life and mine? Traditionally, we have applied these parables to the Christian experience, saying that anyone who follows after Jesus Christ should first count the cost of that diseipleship. And this seems to be the obvious application since Jesus Him self said likewise, whosoever he be of you that forsaketh not all that he hath, he cannotbe my disciple. However, there might be another application which isnt so obvious. When Jesus spoke these parables, the inevitability of the Cross loomed large on the horikon. Jesus has begun to tell the disciples of His impending suffering and death and no doubt, He knew what the immediate reaction would be from the disciples as they witnessed His death. They would be frightened, puzzl ed, disappointed, and dis illusioned, and ask ques tions liké Was Jesus really the Messiah, and if so, why did He die . . . Does this mean the actually death of God Himself? So. then, Jesus, who knew how these men would view the Cross, seems to be suggesting to them with these parables that there is no unfinished business,, no unfinished towers, and no unwon wars with God - the Cross would not mean the defeat of Gad and His Kingdom of right eousness. What God begins.

document.text: y. moving an inch or two of snow can prove fatal. And it isnt the shoveling itself tiiat is the problem. It is the way we go aboutit. -, Bates explained that most people-try to do too much too. quickly, too fast shoveling great mounds of snow and working very quickly. The combination of heavy snow and rapid working pace puts a great strain on our system---és- pecially when we are not in condition. - The Blue Cross and Blue Shield fitness specialist re commended some precaution ary measures that can reduce thé dangers associated with snow shoveling. 1. Use s short shovel, with a small scoop. 2. Lift small loads, not large ones dont fill the scoop , completely as you shovel. - 3. Warm-up slowly and then pace yourself stop to rest often-before you feel tired. 4. Dress warmly but dont overdo it too many layers of clothes work to trap body heat, placing still more strain on your cardivascular system. Bates emphasized th at people with high blood pressure suffer from angina, or are otherwise a high risk for heart attacks should not shovel snow under any circumstances. According to Bates, women are more -often more fit than men for snow shoveling. For one thing women have some natural protection against heart attack. Women often are in better physical condition than men, too, Bates continued, noting that- this is ini- part a  consequence of the work that  women do to keep their homes. Men are often disdain ful of such household activities as sweeping, mopping, and vacuuming because they dont fit with the traditional macho male image, he said. How ever such activities actually help strengthen the arm and back muscles, and the fact, that women are left to do these things contributes to the superior conditioning that many women enjoy. Men who want to get in shape would do well to pitch in and help with household chores especially if they spend their days sitting at - a desk. Bates concluded, We all need to become more physically fit. If youre not in shape this winter, start now to become more physically fit. If youre not in shape now start now to get yourself in,condition.

document.text: xpress was so badly hurt that there is little hope of his recovery. Both the express and the trolley were on steep grades, going at right angles. The express was signaled and the cross ing gates were lowered while the trolley car was half way down the hill. The motorman shut off the power and ap plied the brakes, but almost immediate ly the car began to slip along the icy rails. It gained tremendous momentum and at the bottom of the hill crashed through the gates directly in the track of the oncoming train. The locomotive plowed its way through the trolley, throwing the children in every direction. The accident happened within three blocks of the HighSchool building, and in the car at the time were nearly 100 pupils. As many as thirty others had managed to throw themselves from the car before the crash came. The trolley was one of the specials which every day bring the children to school. It had more than its ordinary load owing to the cold. It contained every child that could squeeze inside, and others stood on the rear platform. Peter Brady, the motorman, promptly shut off the power and applied the brakes. The speed of the car was checked, gut it continued to move slow ly down the incline. There was no thought of danger. Then it began to j move faster and faster. The ice covered

document.text: Wren Nests in Mans Coat. W hile two men were cutting the wood in a coppice near Chandlers Cross, on the borders of Herts and Bucks, England, they erected a tem porary shelter, in which one of them left his coat hanging for a few days. When he went to remove it he found i wrens nest cleverly built in one of the pockets. He replaced the coat, rad during the last week the bird has aid several eggs in the nest. The woodman has decided to allow her to Latch her eggs undisturbed.

document.text: Wounded and Decorated With the Cross Of St. George. Moscow.Among the wounded who have arrived in Moscow from the front is Olga Krasilnikoff, a girl of 19 years. After taking part in 19 battles in Poland she was wounded in the foot. The girl enlisted under a mans name and this deception has just been dis covered. The Cross of St. George, fourth degree, has been awarded to her.

document.text: Would Drop Old Glory. Harrisburg, Pa. Special.Asking-to be registered as the candidate of the Jesus Christ Party for governor, a man from a southwestern county whose name is not disclosed sent a emmun ca tion to the State Department. In his platform he declares for the substitution of the cross for the Stars and Stripes, the prohibition of all religions except the Christian, prohibition of low wages, like wise of gossip, substituting a flat 5 per cent, assessment on all possessions for other forms of taxation, and permitting women to vote.

document.text: would chance on the Corny half a dollar a day, and the lat ter took the place of the dollar-a-day man, who drank too much to hold his job, and accepted the otter and the red flag with an eagerness that almost made Mahoney wish he had knocked off an additional half dol nr. Cornys place was at the narre w crossing at Blank street, where n plat form of heavy planks had been built over the deep ditch of the subway works. At one end of the excavation was the hoisting engine house, and overhead the heavy wire cables carried the trolley car of earth or broken stone from the further end of the ditch to the dumping platform near the en gine. Beside the engineer was a window, and through this nperture he could see the boy with the flag at the cross ing, a long block away. He governed tue speed and the raising and lowering of the car according to the signal of that flag. Corny received his signals from the man who stood directly above the spot where the men were excavating, and who guided the swinging liox among the great pipes and drains aiul conduits which seemed to hang In a perfect network above the heads of the labor ers below, Besides keeping a sharp eye on the man, Corny was expected to be on the lookout for vehicles that wished to cross the ditch mid to allow none to cross while the loaded trolley wns run ning overbend. A bit of rock might fall from the car, or a horse might become frightened by the rattle of the trolley. The flagboy certainly enrned his half dollar. There was no time for sky larking, even had Corny been so in clined. But Maboney had been quite correct In his judgment of Cornys face life was altogether too serious to him for the flagboy to enjoy him self ns did other boys. When a person of fifteen feels the responsibility of forty-five resting on his shoulders skylarking Is a long way from his thoughts. The pitiable three dollars a week Mahoney allowed him was expected, with what Johhny could darn doing chores for the local store keepers and Ben could make selling papers to clothe, feed and house seven ravenously hungry, active growing boys and girls. It bad not always been so. Six months of trial and privation bad made a very old-fashioned boy Indeed of Cornelius Harney. The Ilarneys had only lived a year and a half In the eltv before the father died. They lntd come from  the old country, and after  hot man was taken, the mother pined more and more for the old English village where she had been born. She count do but little to help support the family, and soon the orphaned children raw her laid away also. Cornelius was the oldest boy. Mary, who was two years Ills senior, kept house for them and tried to keep the garments of the younger children de cently patched. Nobody seemed to want a boy of Cornelius age until be bad drawn the attention of Boss Ma honey at the underground works. Those three dollars looked big indeed to Corny until lie began to try to ap portion them outso much toward the rent, so much for food, and such a very little for clothing, and nothing at all for extras. Johnnys and Bens incomes were not to be depended upon, for they varied according to the num ber of errands Johnny could run and tile number of papers Ben sold. And to make sure of those three dol lars Corney had to be up at 6 every morning, rain or shine, warm or cold, and. be did not get back until ! at night. There certainly was no thought of play in the Ungboys mind. The re sponsibilities resting on bis young shoulders spurned Corny to do his best Ho quickly learned the signals by which tlie engine was governed, and lie was never inattentive when the trolley was in motion. Mahoney ad mitted that the kid was a good And for him but be still appropriated the other three dollars in Cornys envelope oil pay day. The timekeeper, who came up from tlie contractors office every afternoon to get tlie details of the days work from Mahoney, gave poor Corny a seri ous fright the very first day.  Wheres McAdo? asked the time keeper, briskly. He was a lively young fellow, who usually had a joke for the men, and be was known to be a rela tive of the contractor himself. McAdo was the name of the man who bad been flagging, and Corny knew it and trembled.  Hes no good, an Ive fired him. Mahoney declared, belligerently. He never seemed to like the timekeeper perhaps because he feared the latters eyes were sharply concerned in his em ployers interest. I dont believe Mr. Buttcrworth will stand for a boy to flag. Something might happen. Now, you let the lad alone, Ma

document.text: Worlds Greatest Hymn Book T ET me write a nations songs, and 1 care not who writes their laws, said a famous man. The same thing can be said about re ligion. Let me write a churchs hymnbook, and I care not who writes their theologies. The hymns our mothers loved, the hymns we heard before we heard any other kind of poetry, the hymns that we have learned by heart and that become a part of our minds these mean far more to most peo ple than all the printed creeds. Now the Christian religion is a singing religion. Our very first hymnbook was the Book of Psalms, and all the hymnals since, down to the present day, grew out of this one book in the Bible. It is the greatest hymn book in the world not the long est nor. the oldest, but the great est in its influence for good upon mankind.    I Poetry Was in Jesus Blood  F OUR Lord Jesus himself, it truly can be said, poetry was in his veins. He came of a poetic family. His most famous ancestor, David, was a poet another royal ancestor, Hezekiah, wrote poetry. The book he knew best, the Old Testament, was full of poetry. His own mother Mary, before he was born, sang a song of her own mak ing, so beautiful that it is still sung in Christian churches and loved the world around. - When Jesus died on the cross, two of the last seven sentences that came from his lips were quotations from the Psalms. The poetry of his people was in his blood, for in his last agony the i words that came from his break ing heart were words first spok- I en by the poets of the Bible long , ago. j So it is always. Truth in song I will tarry long. Today and al-  ways, the parts of the Bible which  are most cherished, the parts most i often learned by heart, the parts  which we carry with us to the val- 1 ley of the shadow of death, are the truths set to music, long centuries ago, by inspired men who knew how to clothe truth with garments of shining and immortal loveliness, j Copyright by tbo InternationaI Council ol I Roligioua Education on boball ol 0 Proton- taut doMomiaatiooM. document.text: WOODSON MARTIN. Concord, Va., June 3, 1895 Seldom has it been our privilege to attend a more beautiful marriage than that which was consummated at Bethleham M. E. Church, last Wednesday evening, at 9 oclock the contracting parties being Mr. Wal ter B. Woodson, a young and rising merchant of this place, and Miss Minnie, the very attractive daughter of Mrs. Emma Martin, also of this town. Long before the appointed hour the church was crowded with friends and relatives anxious to witness this popular couple united in the holy bonds of wedlock. Promptly at the appointed hour the dnlect and in spiring strains of Tanhausers wed ding mach, under the masterly touch of Mrs. G. Norman Abbitt, proclaimed the entry of the bridal cortege. The order of the atteu dants was as follows Miss Nannie Wharton aud Mr Eddie Franklin Miss Sallie Ariing- on and Mr. Miles Shipman Miss Della Steele and Mr. Thesis Lindsay Miss Ruby Woodson and Mr. Rees Evans Miss Ada Staples and Mr. J. L Woodson Miss Evie Martin and Mr. Courtney Thomas Miss Jnlia Woodson and Mr. Edwin Franklin Miss Marie L. Ould and Mr. W.C. Tanner Miss Lula Conch and Mr. Orville Van B. Thompson The pretty little flower bearers enter ed in the following order Miss Katie Carson and Pearl Woodson Miss Jessie Martin and Evelyn Moore Miss Nellie Abbott, Gracie Cross and Johnie Martin. Then appeared the pretty ank blushing bride-elect, with beauti-e ful bouquet of rare spring flowers leaning on the arm of her maid of honor, Miss Florrie Arrington, who were met in front of the chan cel by Mr. Woodson with his best man, Mr. Jno. G. Fisher. There beneath a beautiful arch aud pendent bell of evergreens and spring flowers, this young couple was joined in the bonds of matri mony, bj the Rev. Mr. Parish,of the Methodist church. The wedding party, preceded by the ushers Messrs, W. L. Peet and R. L. Staples with a large number of invited guests re paired immediately to the hospitable home of Mrs. Victoria and Ann E Arrington where a sumptuous dinner awaited them. The happy couple departed Thurs day morning at 120 on the Norfolk and Western east-bound train for Richmond and other points of inter est, accompanied by the well wishes of a large circle of friends. Q u id N u n c .

document.text: wood lot, must devise some other way of holding the Christmas tree In posi tion. The easiest way to do this, if the tree Is not too- large and heavy, is to insert the trunk into the hole through the bottom of a wooden box, and either paint this box green or red or cover it with green or red paper. A starch box will hold up a small tree perfectly, but a somewhat larger box must be chosen for one of larger growth. If, in spite of all precautions, tlie tree seems too heavy and Is in clined to wobble, weight the box on either side with heavy stones. Some times the box is filled with sand, the trunk planted in that, and then the wooden cover nailed n place to make all very solid. If oneas any talent for carpentry, even of the roughest sort, an effective support can be made by nailing two pieces of wood in the shape of a square cross, holding the tree upon this and nailing cleats to both tree and support until it stands firmly. A very pretty effect can be obtained by covering the support of the tree and the floor directly around it with white cotton batting on which silver tinsel, called rain in most shops, has been sprinkled. This makes the tree look as if it were growing In a bunch of snow glittering in the sun.

document.text: Women Now Eligible to V. C. A royal warrant consolidating and extending provisional royal warrants regarding the Victoria Cross was pub lished recently in the London Gazette. The principal feature Is that women are now made eligible for decoration, It being ordained that matrons, sis ters, nurses and the staff of the nurs ing services and other services per taining to hospitals and nursing, and civilians of either sex serving regu larly or temporarily under the orders, direction or supervision of any of the armed forces of the crown, shall b eligible to tbe cross.

document.text: Wlth the exhaust gas heater some form of regulating valve should be used and a few cross partitions in the inlet pipe at the point where the heat is applied help heat the center of the column of the entering mixture. Gaso line will stand about eighty-five pounds compression without pre-ignltlon. Kerosene, however, will not stand over seventy pounds unless a small quantity of water is taken into the cylinder with each charge. The customary man ner of doing this is to employ either a separate small carburetor for the water or a small valve attached to the regular carburetor. In a few engines the water Is Injected directly Into the cylinder. The proportion of water employed is about one and one-half pints of wa ter to each gallon of kerosene. If the water is not used when the motor has the usual compression employed for gasoline the motor will pre-ignite and Is very apt to burn out the connecting rod bearings. It is not generally known that water may be used to advantage with gasoline In about the same pro portion with considerable saving of fuel.

document.text: witness said Beatty suggested croton oil, and I said no, that waa dangerous, and Dempsey said he knew a powder which would be better. Dempsey said he had used these powders to Chicago and he had broken a strike to four days. It is not dangerous. Dempsey said be would guarantee us fifty dollars each and our expens. Wegot no powders that day. We then left tbe hall together and talked about it. Beatty said we were to get fifty dollars each, and we were to get a gold watch and chain if we went. David son sid that of tbe fifty dollars promised him he got bat fourteen dollars. Attorney Brennen subjected the .witness to a severe cross eassitStioa, hut did not materially weaken Us evidence. Davidron, however, admitted that he was arrested late in November and taken into the St.- Nicholas building and waa sworn, and told the story he had just told. Then he was released. Gallagher was arrested before that. He said they had it down to black and white, and he had to tell all he knew. Mr. BrennenAre you to get a diamond watch for this? Oh, yes I guess so like the one I got from Dempsey. Captain BeckYqu were promised noth ing for coming here, were you? No, sir. J. H. Ford, a detective, swore I know Beatty, Gallagher and Davidson. On Dec. 1 1 heard a conversation between Beatty, Gallagher and Davidson, to which Beatty told abont the powders and .what they con tained. Gallagher said he believed if Dempsey was home the strike would be won, but Beatty said he thought not. I heard Gallager say Tom Brady first sug gested croton oil. On Dec. 4 1 overheard a talk between Gallagher and Beatty, which was about the same as the former one. Beatty said Turkish rhubarb end snuff was in tha powders and it was not necessary to tell the rest. Gallagher said he could take the powders and go west add break np some strike there, and told Beatty to go to Homestead next day and get the receipt if he had to pay five dollars, as there was money to it for both of them.  Louis Welters, steward of the restaurant to tbe Homestead mill, testified that he noticed unaccountable sickness soon after employing Gallagher as a cook. He said that to spite of the best of food he and his wife become very ill, and bad never fully recovered. He had several times seen  Beatty talking to Gallagher to tbe mill. Beatty was held in 5,000 bail for trial at court. - _____ _ A Flood Test Sait. P ittsburg , Dec. 19.Suit has been en tered to the United States circuit court agtenstthe South Fork Fishing club by Jffiies Jenktos and wife, of Youngstown, O in the right of Mrs. Jenkins for 20,000 damages for injuries received to the Johns town flood. This is the first suit ever en tered directly against the South Fork club for its connection with the flood, and is re garded as a test suit.

document.text: With U. S. Naval Forces On The Rhine.- Shelton C. Gallier19, seaman first class, USNR, was among the men of our amphibious Navy who helped carry Allied ar mies across the Rhine. He is the son of Mrs. Annie GaPer, R. F. D. f, Appomatox, Va. Nevor be fore had the Army called a the Navy to heln it cross an inland river. The Navy did the job 200 miles from the nearest ocean. Gal- lier was thus pari of the - forces which made Naval history. He and his fellow amphibians trained se cretly for months along smaller rivers in France and Belgium. Thqy even wore army uniforms and helmets, and slogged through mud with he doughboys. Even their boats were disguised.. hulls painted the Armys olive- drab. Many of the boats were trans- ror ed as far as 300 miles, along blasted roads, makeshift t bridges, and village streets. Manned by Qallier and his mates, LCMls and LCVPs are still racing back and forth across the Rhine, their bow- ramps disgorging soldiers, tanks, runs and supplies on the east bank for the final drive through Germany.
